Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 218,.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 218, Section 3.

Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.raw_text: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc., 448 Mass. 780 (2007).
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.proposition: Defendant HomeGoods Superstore, LLC, owed a duty of care to maintain a safe shopping environment for its customers, including Plaintiff, by ensuring that items on shelves were properly secured to prevent foreseeable harm.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly adopts a modern premises-liability standard for self-service retail operations, holding that store owners have a duty to take reasonable precautions commensurate with foreseeable risks created by their chosen mode of operation. While the facts involve grapes on a supermarket floor rather than unsecured shelf items, the court’s reasoning is general: a self-service store must maintain its premises in a reasonably safe condition and foresee and guard against hazards inherent in how merchandise is displayed and accessed. This directly supports the broader proposition that a self-service retailer like HomeGoods owes customers a duty of care to maintain a safe shopping environment and to prevent foreseeable harms arising from how items are presented to customers.
Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.relevant_excerpt: Courts adopting this approach have concluded that where an owner’s chosen mode of operation makes it reasonably foreseeable that a dangerous condition will occur, a store owner could be held liable for injuries to an invitee if the plaintiff proves that the store owner failed to take all reasonable precautions necessary to protect invitees from these foreseeable dangerous conditions… Adoption of this approach would not hold owners strictly liable… but would only make an owner liable if the owner could reasonably foresee that a dangerous condition exists and failed to take adequate steps to forestall resulting injuries.

Altman v. Aronson, 231 N.E.2d 4 (1967)..proposition: Defendant HomeGoods Superstore, LLC, owed a duty of care to maintain a safe shopping environment for its customers, including Plaintiff, by ensuring that items on shelves were properly secured to prevent foreseeable harm.
Altman v. Aronson, 231 N.E.2d 4 (1967)..support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with criminal procedure and the suppression of a custodial statement under Miranda, not premises liability or a store’s duty of care to customers. It does not address any duty to maintain a safe shopping environment, secure items on shelves, or any tort or negligence principles related to business invitees. Therefore, it does not support the stated proposition about HomeGoods’ duty of care.
Altman v. Aronson, 231 N.E.2d 4 (1967)..relevant_excerpt: Our Code of Criminal Procedures purports to cover only pretrial motions to suppress confessions or to suppress physical evidence obtained under illegal search and seizure. If the ground for either of said motions exists and is known to the defendant prior to trial, our statute contemplates that the motion shall be made prior to trial.

Hone v. Shaw, 45 Mass. 362, 362 (1842)..proposition: Defendant HomeGoods Superstore, LLC, owed a duty of care to maintain a safe shopping environment for its customers, including Plaintiff, by ensuring that items on shelves were properly secured to prevent foreseeable harm.
Hone v. Shaw, 45 Mass. 362, 362 (1842)..support_reasoning: The opinion in Hone v. Shaw concerns the legality and structure of criminal sentences for larceny and escape from confinement under Massachusetts statutes. It does not discuss premises liability, duties of care owed by businesses to customers, or any aspect of tort law or safe shopping environments. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition that HomeGoods owed a duty to maintain safely secured items on shelves.
Hone v. Shaw, 45 Mass. 362, 362 (1842)..relevant_excerpt: "To reverse a judgment for error, it must appear erroneous on the face of the record. A judgment is entitled at least to so much respect as to be deemed good, unless some error is shown..." (This and the rest of the opinion focus entirely on criminal sentencing issues, not duties of care to customers.)

Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928).
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..proposition: Defendant HomeGoods Superstore, LLC, owed a duty of care to maintain a safe shopping environment for its customers, including Plaintiff, by ensuring that items on shelves were properly secured to prevent foreseeable harm.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..support_reasoning: Palsgraf concerns the relational nature and scope of duty and foreseeability in negligence, not any specific retail-store duty to secure merchandise on shelves. Cardozo’s opinion limits duty to those within the range of reasonably foreseeable risk; it does not establish a general affirmative duty like that claimed for HomeGoods, nor does it address premises liability or store safety standards. Thus, citing Palsgraf as direct authority that a retailer owes a duty to maintain safe shelving is inaccurate, even though the case is relevant to the broader concept of duty and foreseeability.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..relevant_excerpt: “In every instance, before negligence can be predicated of a given act, back of the act must be sought and found a duty to the individual complaining, the observance of which would have averted or avoided the injury… The risk reasonably to be perceived defines the duty to be obeyed, and risk imports relation; it is risk to another or to others within the range of apprehension.”

Fredericks v. Conaway, 460 Mass. 309 (20.proposition: Defendant HomeGoods Superstore, LLC, owed a duty of care to maintain a safe shopping environment for its customers, including Plaintiff, by ensuring that items on shelves were properly secured to prevent foreseeable harm.
Fredericks v. Conaway, 460 Mass. 309 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion in Fredericks v. Conaway (as provided) involves a criminal prosecution for murder, arson, and related offenses, and analyzes issues such as the merger doctrine in felony-murder, jury instructions, and ineffective assistance of counsel. It does not concern premises liability, retail store duties, or any civil duty of care owed by a business like HomeGoods to customers. Therefore, it does not establish or discuss a duty to maintain safe shelving or prevent falling merchandise, and cannot support the cited negligence proposition.
Fredericks v. Conaway, 460 Mass. 309 (20.relevant_excerpt: Because the provided text is a criminal case about murder, arson, and armed home invasion, there is no passage addressing duties of retail stores to maintain safe shopping environments or secure items on shelves.

Care & Protection of Martha, 417 Mass. 7.proposition: Defendant HomeGoods Superstore, LLC, owed a duty of care to maintain a safe shopping environment for its customers, including Plaintiff, by ensuring that items on shelves were properly secured to prevent foreseeable harm.
Care & Protection of Martha, 417 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The case is a landlord‑tenant, implied warranty of habitability and damages opinion involving a subsidized residential apartment. It does not involve a retail store, premises liability, or a merchant’s duty to maintain safe conditions for customers or to secure items on shelves. The principles discussed concern the measure of damages for breach of the implied warranty of habitability in subsidized housing, not a commercial store’s duty of care to invitees, so it does not support the cited proposition about HomeGoods’ duty to shoppers.
Care & Protection of Martha, 417 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “(a) The HAP contract between MHFA and Cruz Management required Cruz Management ‘to provide Decent, Safe and Sanitary housing.’ … A tenant’s action for a breach of the implied warranty of habitability (or a counterclaim on this ground) serves the related purpose of forcing a landlord to repair defects in a substandard housing unit.”

Doe v. Harvard Pilgrim Health Care, Inc..proposition: Defendant HomeGoods Superstore, LLC, owed a duty of care to maintain a safe shopping environment for its customers, including Plaintiff, by ensuring that items on shelves were properly secured to prevent foreseeable harm.
Doe v. Harvard Pilgrim Health Care, Inc..support_reasoning: The opinion is an attorney disciplinary decision involving misappropriation of client funds and related ethical violations; it does not concern premises liability, retail stores, duties of merchants to customers, or shelf safety. There is no discussion of a duty of care owed by a store like HomeGoods to maintain a safe shopping environment or to secure items on shelves. Accordingly, this case does not provide authority for the stated proposition.
Doe v. Harvard Pilgrim Health Care, Inc..relevant_excerpt: Based on these findings, as well as others not relevant to this appeal, the single justice affirmed the board’s finding of multiple violations of S.J.C. Rule 3:07... [regarding] intentionally misappropriating client funds... We affirm the decision of the single justice ordering disbarment.

Morrison v. Medford Coop. Bank, 1 N.E.2d.raw_text: Morrison v. Medford Coop. Bank, 1 N.E.2d 1003 (1936).

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.proposition: Defendant HomeGoods Superstore, LLC, owed a duty of care to maintain a safe shopping environment for its customers, including Plaintiff, by ensuring that items on shelves were properly secured to prevent foreseeable harm.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.support_reasoning: The case concerns a racetrack’s alleged duty to alter or control a state highway to protect patrons crossing between a parking lot and the track, not a retail store’s duty to maintain safe conditions inside its premises or secure items on shelves. The court ultimately holds that the landowner’s duty generally does not extend to adjacent public streets it does not control, and it expressly declines to expand premises liability in that way. Although the opinion restates the general rule that owners must maintain their premises in reasonably safe condition, the holding does not address or support the specific proposition about securing merchandise on store shelves.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739 (.relevant_excerpt: It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.... Although a landowner or possessor typically is not held to any duty with respect to public highways adjacent to or crossing his land, he must exercise reasonable care in the use of his land so as not to injure a traveler on the highway.
